Topic.Title: US Is Secretly Collecting Records of Verizon Calls

Message.Msg: Bush and Obama have done the exact same thing here. The program actually began in February, 2001-- a month after Bush/Cheney took office and 7 months before 9/11. It was first revealed in 2006. Many, like me, had hoped it had died with the Bush presidency but there was no way of knowing. Now it appears it hasn't. I was very upset about the program then and I am very upset about it now. Few of you seem to recall that Bush/Cheney pushed a program called Total Information Awareness, which was supposed to collect all available "business" records, including credit card, internet activity, etc. When this became public knowledge, the program was defunded by Congress and supposedly split into several unrelated, secret projects. The last vestiges of Bush era of thinking needs to go. This includes secret courts, secret prisons, torture, the concept of enemy combatants and the idea that the government should be collecting massive amounts of data on the US population.

Topic.Title: US Is Secretly Collecting Records of Verizon Calls

Message.Msg: "this administration found ways to greatly expand its application." No, they did not. This program has been in place since 2001. What was revealed was a reauthorization of an ongoing program that was first revealed in 2006. Many of us had hoped that Obama had ended it, but since it is a secret program there was no way of knowing. If you want to address this, you need to understand that it is much broader than "I don't like Obama".

Topic.Title: If you

Message.Msg: In June of 2003, $996.45 would have bought 39 shares of T at $25.55/share. That investment would have returned $581.57 in dividends alone over a ten year period. Had you sold T at yesterday's closing price ($35.81), you would have earned an additional $400.14 on your investment for a total return of $981.70 or 99% over ten years (slightly under 10% return annually for very little risk). If you had reinvested your dividends, of course, those returns would be considerably better. T is not a rockstar stock pick but it has a justifiable place in many portfolios. I appreciate your enthusiasm for WIN but you may want to consider the "if you" scenario for WIN since its IPO. You will quickly see that the stock has lost close to half of its value and the dividend hasn't increased in over 6 years. Historically speaking, WIN has not been better.

Message.Msg: ..#$%$ Cheney to Compete in 1 Shot Antelope Hunt LANDER, Wyo. (Routers) #$%$ Cheney will be shooting for Wyoming in this year's One Shot Antelope Hunt, picked for the three man team by Wyoming Gov. Matt Mead. Members of each three-person hunting team are allowed one shot to kill an antelope. The team that kills the most antelope in the shortest time wins. The third Wyoming team member isn't expected to be announced until August. A replacement has to be found for the previously selected team member, Attorney Fasil Blastoff, who had to withdraw from the competition because of an earlier incident in team practice, when Cheney accidentally shot him in the face.
